description: From Middle English comparen, from Old French comparer, from Latin comparare (“to prepare, procure”), from compar (“like or equal to another”), from com- + par (“equal”). Displaced native Old English metan (“to compare,” also “to measure”).

examples: Their small galleys may not hold compare with our tall ships.

entries.meaning: (countable, programming) An instruction or command that compares two values or states.
examples: […]  including addition and subtraction, memory operations, compares, shifts, logic operations, and condition operations.

verbs.description: compare (third-person singular simple present compares, present participle comparing, simple past and past participle compared)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To assess the similarities and differences between two or more things ["to compare X with Y"]. Having made the comparison of X with Y, one might have found it similar to Y or different from Y.
examples: Compare the tiger's coloration with that of the zebra.
You can't compare my problems and yours.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To declare two things to be similar in some respect ["to compare X to Y"].
examples: Astronomers have compared comets to dirty snowballs.

entries.meaning: (transitive, grammar) To form the three degrees of comparison of (an adjective).
(intransitive) To be similar (often used in the negative).
examples: A sapling and a fully-grown oak tree do not compare.
